captions.text:
I consider myself an expert on the subject
of grace. Not because I understand it better

than anyone else, in fact most times I'm left
completely clueless as to what grace actually

is. I just know it when I see it, and I know
it when I experience it because frankly, I've

needed a lot of it in my life. So I guess
I'm not an expert, just I have a lot of practice.

But even with all the years of messing up
and needing what Christians call "God's grace,"

I'm still left struggling with the most basic
of questions: what is grace? You see, I think

way too often we in the Church overcomplicate
something that, at its purest form, could

not be more simple. You see, grace is gained
righteousness at Christ's expense, meaning

that with Jesus's death on the cross, he purchased
for us a right relationship with God that

we could not earn for ourselves because grace
is received and can't be earned, and once

this gift is realized, it adequately covers
everything, meaning every debt is cancelled,

every single sin past present and future,
so get ready and come expectantly because

grace is a growing revolution and carnal execution,
meaning that as we leave the flesh behind

and as we die more and more to ourselves,
we are stepping into a movement that continues

to change the world by giving redemption and
communion to everyone. God is granting rest

after condemnation ends because a gap has
been realized and connected entirely. A bridge

has been built. The battle has been won. And
God reigns and Christ is exalted. So simply

put, grace is proof that God really always
can endure.

comments.text:
God's grace is easy. That's kind of the whole reason Jesus died on the 
cross. So that we didn't have to grovel, and beg, and make sacrifices 
anymore. He gives it to us freely because we are His favored creation. It 
seems you need to reread the New Testament a bit.

comments.author: The Amazing Shrek

comments.text:
if God's favor has to be earned, then no one gets it. He has a standard and 
criteria we can't fulfill because of our imperfection. As a just God, He 
has to give the punishment for sin. But as a loving God, He gave the 
punishment to Jesus instead of us. And Jesus traded his righteousness(the 
standard and criteria) for our sins and brought it to the grave with him. 
salvation is not about what we do. it's about what Christ has already done 
for us. Jesus is the grace of God.
comments.author: Doodle Productions

I see what you did there.. hah. Pretty cool though. If you want a good 
place to study Grace pick a book by John Bevere called Extraordinary. He 
explains grace from an entirely different angle, grace is a power, it is 
what we need to be able to perform those acts which we are called to do, 
but by our own earthly selves could not. It's what empowers us to not just 
be earthly beings but to live extroardinary supernatural lives!!﻿
